column1: Santa Maria Capua Vetere (Neapolitan: Santa Maria 'e Capua) is a town and comune in the province of Caserta
column2: part of the region of Campania (southern Italy).

column1: Though it is not connected with the Civitas Capuana
column2: the town is a medieval place and its proximity to the Roman amphitheatre led the inhabitants to change its name in Santa Maria Capua Vetere
column3: where Capua Vetere means Old Capua.

column1: == History ==
For the history of ancient Capua
column2: see Capua Antica.  In the area several settlements of the Villanovan culture were present in pre-historical times
column3: and these were probably enlarged by the Oscans and Etruscans. In the 4th century BCE Capuae was the largest city in Italy after Rome.

column1: The city was damaged by Vandal ravages but later recovered and became the seat of an independent Lombard principate. However
column2: during the struggle of the succession to the Duchy of Benevento
column3: it was destroyed by a band of Saracens in 841 CE. The survivors mostly fled and founded the modern Capua in the site of the ancient River port of Casilinum.

column1: What is now Santa Maria Capua Vetere started to grow slowly when several countryside residences appeared around the old Christian basilicas of Santa Maria Maggiore
column2: San Pietro in Corpo and Sant'Erasmo in Capitolio. King Robert of Anjou made Santa Maria Maggiore one of his summer residences.

column1: The town was known as Santa Maria Maggiore until 1861.

The main other landmark of Santa Maria Capua Vetere is the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore
column4: by Pope Symmachus in the 5th century. The church had originally a single nave
column5: but was enlarged by Lombard Prince Arechis II of Benevento in 787. Another renovation was carried out in 1666 by Cardinal Robert Bellarmine
column6: with the addition of two further aisles; the current Late Baroque appearance dates to the 1742–88 works
column7: during which the precious mosaic area of the apse was destroyed.
